page.title: List of box office records set by Avatar

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of box office records set by ''Avatar''}} [[File:James Cameron by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|250px|[[James Cameron]] wrote, directed, and produced ''Avatar''.|alt=A photograph of James Cameron]] ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' was released in December 2009 and went on to break multiple [[box office]] records in various markets. Worldwide, it became the [[List of highest-grossing films|highest-grossing movie of all time]]<ref name=":0" /> and the [[List of fastest-grossing films|fastest movie to gross]] $1 billion through $2.5 billion,<ref name=":58" /><ref name=":59" /><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":60" /><ref name=":61" /> while also setting the records for the highest grosses in the [[3D film|3D]]<ref name="boxofficemojo1" /> and [[IMAX]]<ref name=":62" /> formats, respectively. In its domestic market of the United States and Canada, it set the records for the [[List of highest-grossing films in the United States and Canada|highest-grossing film]]<ref name=":63" /> and [[List of highest-grossing second weekends for films|second]] through seventh weekends,<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":23" /><ref name=":24" /><ref name=":25" /><ref name=":26" /><ref name=":27" /> as well as the fastest to gross $500 million through $750 million.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":18" /><ref name=":19" /><ref name=":20" /><ref name=":21" /><ref name=":22" /> Elsewhere, it became the highest-grossing film of all time in over 30 markets including [[List of highest-grossing films in China|China]],<ref name=":48" /> [[List of highest-grossing films in Hong Kong|Hong Kong]],<ref name="boxofficemojo1" /><ref name="hollywoodreporter2" /><ref name=":49" /> [[List of highest-grossing films in Romania|Romania]],<ref name="boxofficemojo1" /> [[List of highest-grossing films in South Korea|South Korea]],<ref name="boxofficemojo3" /><ref name=":53" /> [[List of highest-grossing films in Taiwan|Taiwan]],<ref name="boxofficemojo5" /> and [[List of highest-grossing films in the United Kingdom|the United Kingdom]].<ref name="boxofficemojo5" />
Box office analysts identified several factors contributing to the film's box office success. Among these were the relative lack of competition owing to the release date, a marketing strategy that emphasized the novelty of the cinematic experience leading viewers to watch it in the theater rather than at home, positive [[word of mouth]] and repeat viewings increasing the film's staying power in cinemas, an ability to attract audiences across the globe, and premium ticket prices from 3D and IMAX showings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/how-avatar-can-beat-titanic-71031|title=How 'Avatar' Can Beat 'Titanic'|date=2010-01-05|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1628513/how-will-avatar-fare-at-the-box-office-experts-weigh-in/|title=How Will 'Avatar' Fare At The Box Office? Experts Weigh In|work=MTV News|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/can-avatar-director-break-his-box-office-record-2010-01-04|title=Can Cameron break his own box-office record?|last=Britt|first=Russ|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1628991/will-avatar-top-james-camerons-titanic-box-office-record/|title=Will 'Avatar' Top James Cameron's 'Titanic' Box-Office Record?|work=MTV News|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/01/03/box-office-avatar-soars-past-1-billion-worldwide/|title=Box Office Report: 'Avatar' is No. 1 again, soars past $1 billion worldwide|last=Vary|first=Adam B.|date=January 2, 2010|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=2018-08-10|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q2lIbBX4?url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/01/03/box-office-avatar-soars-past-1-billion-worldwide/|archivedate=May 27, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=mdy}}</ref> Many of the records set by the film are listed below. Data on the previous record and records that have since been surpassed are presented where available and applicable. All grosses are given in unadjusted [[United States dollar|US dollars]], except where noted otherwise.
== Worldwide == The film set the worldwide record for the highest gross of all time, surpassing the previous record by more than 50%<!-- $2,788.0 million / $1,843.2 million = 1.512... > 1.50 -->, and grossed $2 billion in less time than it had taken the previous fastest-grossing film to gross half as much<!-- 47 days for Avatar to $2 billion vs. 63 days for Dead Man's Chest to $1 billion -->. It also exceeded the previous record for highest gross in the IMAX format by a factor of more than three<!-- $243 million / $71 million = 3.42... > 3 -->. {| class="wikitable" |+ !Record !Figure !Previous record holder !Surpassed by !Notes |- |[[List of highest-grossing films|Highest-grossing film]] |$2.78 billion<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/world/|title=All Time Worldwide Box Office Grosses|last=|first=|date=|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref> |''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' – $1.84 billion<ref revision.comment: {{Short description|The Lost Blue Bucket Mine is a lost mine reputed to be located along the Meek Cutoff trail in Oregon}}
revision.text:
{{Short description|The Lost Blue Bucket Mine is a lost mine reputed to be located along the Meek Cutoff trail in Oregon}}
[[Image:Joda sheeprock.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[John Day River]] passing by Sheep Rock in the [[John Day Fossil Beds National Monument]]; the mine is thought to be near the John Day River]] The '''Lost Blue Bucket Mine''' is a [[Lost mines|lost mine]] reputed to be located along the [[Meek Cutoff|Meek Wagon Train]] trail between the present day cities of [[Vale, Oregon|Vale]] and [[The Dalles, Oregon|The Dalles]] in [[Oregon]], United States. Its discovery traces back to 1845, several years before the start of the [[California Gold Rush]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bowmanmuseum.org/files/Newsletter_June_2010.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725100423/http://www.bowmanmuseum.org/files/Newsletter_June_2010.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }}</ref>
==The legend==
===Points of agreement===
The various versions of the legend tend to agree on a few key points <ref name="thegeozone.com">The Lost Blue Bucket Mine: [http://www.thegeozone.com/treasure/nevada/tales/nv002a.jsp The Lost Blue Bucket Mine], accessdate: April 13, 2017</ref>:
# Lost Oregon-bound emigrants discovered it in summer 1845, # The deposit is coarse [[placer gold]] in a dry [[stream bed]] or [[canyon]], # The canyon is bottomed with [[lava]] pocked with cavities and [[potholes]]. [[File:Covered Wagon on Trail sketch.png|350px|thumb|left|border|A drawing of a pioneer [[covered wagon]]]]
===Versions of the legend===
One version states that a [[wagon train]] got lost off the [[Meek Cutoff]] of the [[Oregon Trail]], near the [[Malheur River]]. Three young men (or boys, or a single girl — accounts vary) went to fetch water, and while doing so put some shiny rocks into a blue bucket. Older members of the party said it was [[copper]]. Someone asked, "Was there much of it?" One replied, "We could have filled one of these blue buckets". This was 1845, before the [[California Gold Rush]], and back then many could not recognize [[gold]]. A Mrs. Fisher kept one [[Gold nugget|nugget]] and left the rest behind. The wagons eventually reached what is now [[The Dalles, Oregon]] in October, 1845. The single nugget was eventually recognized as gold.
Another version holds that when the [[Stephen Meek]] Wagon train stopped along the trail in present-day [[Crook County, Oregon|Crook County]] near Bear Creek, children went to gather water at some distance from the camp. They returned with a blue bucket filled with shiny pebbles. An old-timer in the party stated that the pebbles were made of copper. One of the families, however, kept several of the pebbles as souvenirs. Years later, and after having moved to California, the family came across the pebbles in a dresser drawer. By this time, the [[California Gold Rush]] had occurred, and the expertise was available to recognize that the pebbles were in fact gold. However, no-one could remember the precise location in which the pebbles had been found.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bowmanmuseum.org/Buybooks2.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223021044/http://www.bowmanmuseum.org/Buybooks2.html |archivedate=2010-12-23 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Johndayrivermap.png|240px|thumb|left|border|The watershed of Oregon's [[John Day River]]]] [[File:Crooked River Map.png|280px|thumb|right|border|The watershed of Oregon's [[Crooked River (Oregon)|Crooked River]]]]
==Results==
The legend sparked a [[gold rush]] to the area of modern-day [[Baker City, Oregon]].<ref name="oregongold.net">Oregon Gold: [http://www.oregongold.net/tag/baker/ Baker - Oregon Gold], accessdate: April 13, 2017</ref>
==Current status==
If the mine existed, its location is unknown; the area comprises perhaps {{convert|40000|sqmi|km2}}. <ref name="thegeozone.com"/> It is believed to be on a [[tributary]] of the [[John Day River]], or in another version, on a Bear Creek tributary of the [[Crooked River (Oregon)|Crooked River]]. There are three real [[Mining|mines]] in the U.S. named the "Blue Bucket", including one in [[Grant County, Oregon]], that are unrelated to the lost mine.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=gnispq:2:::NO::P1_FNAME,P1_CLASS:Blue_Bucket_Mine,Mine |title=GNIS query "Blue Bucket Mine"}}</ref>
==Further reading== *{{cite book |title= The Search for Oregon's Lost Blue Bucket Mine: The Stephen Meek Wagon Train of 1845 : An Oregon Documentary |last= Hoffman |first= Charles |author2=Bert Webber |authorlink2=Ebbert Webber |year= 1992}} *{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=J8IdAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA177&lpg=RA1-PA177&dq=%22Blue+Bucket%22+Oregon&source=bl&ots=5WmKyg5VHn&sig=UODG7if3gDcWNujk14k5dJHi4Z0&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result |title=Oregon: Her History, Her Great Men, Her Literature |last= Horner |first= John B. |year= 1919}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links and references== {{More footnotes|date=April 2009}} *{{cite web |url= http://gesswhoto.com/bluebucket.html |title= In Quest of the Blue Bucket Mine, May 02, 1919 |year= 1998 |last= Luce |first= Clay |publisher= Roxann Gess Smith |accessdate= January 22, 2009}} *{{cite web |url= http://www.legendsofamerica.com/OR-BlueBucket.html |title= Oregon Legends: The Lost Blue Bucket Mine |publisher= Legends of America: A Travel Site for the Nostalgic & Historic Minded |accessdate= January 22, 2009}} * {{cite journal|first=Leslie M. |last=Scott |authorlink=Leslie M. Scott |title=[[wikisource:en:Oregon Historical Quarterly/Volume 20/News and Comment from Number 2|Where was Blue Bucket?]] |work=Oregon Historical Quarterly |volume=20 |date=1919 }}
[[Category:Gold mining]] [[Category:Lost mines|Blue Bucket Mine]] [[Category:History of Oregon]] [[Category:Oregon Trail]] [[Category:Crook County, Oregon]] [[Category:Baker County, Oregon]] [[Category:Grant County, Oregon]]

revision.text:
'''The Museum of Sugar''' (in [[Brazilian Portuguese]]: ''Museu do Açúcar'') was a [[museum]] devoted to the history of the [[sugar industry in Brazil]]. It was envisioned by Gil de Methódio Maranhão and created on August 3, 1960 by Resolution 1745 of the [[Institute of Sugar and Alcohol]] (IAA).
The first exhibition was in [[Rio de Janeiro]] at IAA headquarters. The museum was relocated to [[Recife]] on January 30, 1961 and into its own building as the ''O Açúcar e o Homem'' (Sugar and Man) exhibit in October 1963. The museum was designed by [[Carlos Antônio Falcão Correia Lima]] in the Casa Forte neighbourhood. The landscaping was planned by agronomist [[Dárdano de Andrade Lima]]. [[Aloísio Magalhães]] organized sugarcane plantings in a design with a vertical [[mill-stone]] from the Vila da Rainha Plantation in [[Rio de Janeiro]] and a horizontal mill-stone from the Camaragibe Plantation in [[Pernambuco]]. The museum acquired an extensive collection of memorabilia and artifacts. Conferences and courses were hosted and the ''Revista do Museu do Açúcar'' (Museum of Sugar Magazine) was published from 1968 until 1973. Authors of articles included José Antônio Gonsalves de Mello, Ariano Suassuna, Fernando Pio, and Jayme Griz.
The Sugar Museum and its holdings were acquired by the Joaquim Nabuco Institute for Social Research, which is now the [[Joaquim Nabuco Foundation]]. The museum and all its patrimony were transferred to the Institute through Law nº 6.456 on 26 October 1977. The museum became the Joaquim Nabuco Foundation's [[Museum of the Northeast Man]], where the archives from the sugar museum are held.<ref>Lúcia Gaspar [http://basilio.fundaj.gov.br/pesquisaescolar_en/index.php?option=com_content&id=973&Itemid=1 Museum of Sugar] Joaquim Nabuco Foundation Librarian</ref>
==See also== *[[Alexander & Baldwin Sugar Museum]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
Source: GASPAR, Lúcia. Museum of Sugar. Pesquisa Escolar On-Line, Joaquim Nabuco Foundation, Recife. Available at: <http://basilio.fundaj.gov.br/pesquisaescolar/>. Accessed: July 11, 2013
{{coord missing|Pernambuco}}
