{{Infobox person | name = Sultana Wahnón | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Sultana Wahnón Bensusan | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|05|08|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Melilla]], Spain | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | other_names = | occupation = Academic, writer | employer = University of Granada | organization = {{ill|Academia de Buenas Letras de Granada|es}} | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | spouse = | children = | awards = | alma_mater = [[University of Granada]] }} '''Sultana Wahnón Bensusan''' (born 8 May 1960) is a Spanish essayist and literary critic, a professor at the [[University of Granada]] specializing in [[literary theory]] and [[comparative literature]].<ref name=Rica>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.revistadelibros.com/articulos/kafka-y-la-tragedia-judia-de-sultana-wahnon |title=Kafka y la historia |trans-title=Kafka and History |first=Álvaro |last=de la Rica |work=[[Revista de Libros]] |language=Spanish |date=1 November 2005 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
==Academic activity== Sultana Wahnón graduated in Spanish Philology in 1982, with a [[Licentiate (degree)#Spain|licentiate]] in the poetry of the National Literature Prize winner {{ill|Miguel Fernández (poet)|es|Miguel Fernández (poeta)|lt=Miguel Fernández}}, a Melillan author to whom she has dedicated two books. Her doctoral thesis, defended in 1987 and published by [[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi]] in 1998, consists of a description of the Spanish fascist aesthetic system and the analysis of its progressive dissolution in postwar literary criticism. Specializing in literary theory, she has written books such as ''Introducción a la historia de las teorías literarias'' (1991)<ref name=Aguirre>{{Cite journal |url=http://webs.ucm.es/info/especulo/numero3/wahnon.htm |title=Sultana Wahnón: Lenguaje y Literatura |first=Joaquín María |last=Aguirre |work=Documentación de las Ciencias de la Información |number=18 |publisher=[[Complutense University of Madrid]] |pages=11–24 |language=Spanish |year=1995 |access-date=27 August 2017}}</ref> and ''Teoría de la literatura y de la interpretación literaria'' (2008).<ref name=Maqueda>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.ogigia.es/OGIGIA7_files/MAQUEDA_CUENCA.pdf |title=Wahnón, S.: Teoría de la literatura y de la interpretación literaria |first=Eugenio |last=Maqueda Cuenca |work=Ogigia |issn=1887-3731 |number=7 |pages=86–88 |language=Spanish |year=2010 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
In 1995 she began a line of research on the theater of [[Federico García Lorca|García Lorca]], a subject on which she continues to work today.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://guadix.ideal.es/guadix/noticias/201502/23/sultana-wahnon-bensusan-y-el-teatro-de-federico-garcia-lorca-en-el-aula-abentofail.html |title=Sultana Wahnón Bensusan y el Teatro de Federico García Lorca en el Aula Abentofail |trans-title=Sultana Wahnón Bensusan and the Theater of Federico García Lorca at the Abentofail Classroom |first=Jesús Javier |last=Pérez |work=[[Ideal (newspaper)|Ideal]] |location=Guadix |language=Spanish |date=23 February 2015 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In 1995 her book ''Lenguaje y literatura'' was released, in which she talks with the main representatives of the [[linguistic turn]] and [[Hermeneutics|hermeneutic]] skepticism.<ref name=Aguirre/> In 2000 she presented her hypothesis on the innocence of Josef K. in ''[[The Trial]]'',<ref name=vio>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/2004/04/17/babelia/1082157433_850215.html |title=Lo que ya vio Franz Kafka |trans-title=What Franz Kafka Already Saw |first=Reyes |last=Mate |work=[[El País]] |language=Spanish |date=17 April 2004 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> which she developed extensively in the book ''Kafka y la tragedia judía'' (2003).<ref name=Rica/><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/cultural/2004/03/20/021.html |title=Josef K., héroe trágico |first=Jon |last=Juaristi |author-link=Jon Juaristi |work=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] |page=21 |language=Spanish |date=20 March 2004 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> The hermeneutic discussion contained in this book is continued in more recent publications such as ''El problema de la interpretación literaria. Fuentes y bases teóricas para una hermenéutica constructiva'' (2009)<ref name=constructiva>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.academiaeditorial.com/web/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/CB-Wahnon-Hernandez-Arias1.pdf |title=Libro Reseñado |trans-title=Book Review |first=Rocío |last=Hernández Arias |work=Crítica Bibliographica |publisher=Academia del Hispanismo |issn=1885-6926 |volume=W |language=Spanish |date=31 May 2010 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> and ''Perspectivas actuales de hermenéutica literaria. Para otra ética de la interpretación'' (2014).
In 1992 Wahnón entered the field of Cultural and Jewish Studies with a work on the Hebrew poetics of [[Moses ibn Ezra]], and another on the role of the [[Wandering Jew]] in ''[[One Hundred Years of Solitude]]''.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2014/04/20/014.html |title=Buendía |first=Jon |last=Juaristi |author-link=Jon Juaristi |work=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] |page=14 |language=Spanish |date=20 April 2014 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> Beginning in 1995, within the framework of the research project Philosophy After the Holocaust, she began a line of research on thought and literature of [[The Holocaust|the Shoah]], for which she authored papers on [[Hannah Arendt]] and [[Elias Canetti]], and the monograph that she coordinated with {{ill|Reyes Mate|es}} for the journal ''Anthropos''.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ii86G7y1TA4C&lpg=PA139&pg=PA139 |title=Pan y rosas: Fundamentos de exclusión social y empoderamiento |trans-title=Bread and Roses: Fundamentals of Social Exclusion and Empowerment |chapter=Qué tipo de fenómeno es la exclusión social |trans-chapter=What Type of Phenomenon is Social Exclusion |first=Fernando |last=Vidal Fernández |publisher=[[Caritas Spain]] |isbn=9788484404248 |page=139 |language=Spanish |date=23 June 2009 |access-date=27 August 2018 |via=Google Books}}</ref> Her most recent work in this line, from 2010, deals with the images of the Holocaust in post-war Spanish poetry.<ref name=Holocausto>{{Cite news |url=https://www.granadahoy.com/ocio/Sultana-Wahnon-Holocausto-poesia-espanola_0_350965567.html |title=Sultana Wahnón busca el Holocausto en la poesía española |trans-title=Sultana Wahnón Seeks the Holocaust in Spanish Poetry |first=Jesús |last=Arias |work=Granada Hoy |location=Granada |language=Spanish |date=16 March 2010 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In this same period she participated in debates on [[anti-Zionism]] and [[antisemitism]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://laquimera.typepad.com/laquimera/2017/01/cr%C3%B3nicas-sobre-el-holocausto.html |title=Crónicas sobre la memoria del Holocausto |trans-title=Chronicles About the Memory of the Holocaust |work=Laquimera |language=Spanish |date=27 January 2017 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
From 2006 to 2007 she contributed to the national newspaper ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]'' with a series of articles on the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-03-05-2006/abc/Opinion/el-holocausto-y-el-presidente-irani_1421384408400.html |title=El Holocausto y el presidente iraní |trans-title=The Holocaust and the Iranian President |first=Sultana |last=Wahnón |work=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] |language=Spanish |date=3 May 2006 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In recent years she has continued to develop this critical activity in some articles on the current university model. In 2014 she published ''En fuga irrevocable. Un ensayo de crítica de la cultura'', which deals with textual proliferation in the cultural and university spheres.
She has dedicated several articles and reviews to contemporary poets and narrators, including [[Iris M. Zavala]], [[Luis García Montero]], José Gutiérrez, {{ill|Miguel d'Ors|es}}, {{ill|Inmaculada Mengíbar|es}}, [[Gregorio Morales]], Francisco Díaz de Castro, [[Rosa Regàs]], and {{ill|Jacinto López Gorgé|es}}.
==Professional career== In 1977 Wahnón began her studies in Hispanic Philology at the [[University of Granada]], where she has developed most of her professional and teaching activities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://laespiral.deusto.es/sultana/ |first=Íñigo |last=Larroque |title=Sultana |work=La Espiral |language=Spanish |date=14 May 2014 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In 1990, she obtained a position as professor of the Department of General Linguistics and Literary Theory. In 2003 she directed the [[Instituto Cervantes]] of Utrecht.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://utrecht.cervantes.es/FichasCultura/Ficha24683_39_1.htm |title=Palacios de invierno, de Gabriel Albiac |publisher=[[Instituto Cervantes]] of Utrecht |language=Spanish |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In 2004 she obtained the chair of Literary Theory and Comparative Literature. From 2008 to 2011 she directed ''Afinidades. Revista de literatura y pensamiento'', a publication of comparative and pro-European character.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://editorial.ugr.es/pages/publicacionesenabierto/afinidades/revista-afinidades |title=Revista Afinidades |publisher=[[University of Granada]] |language=Spanish |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://elfarodemelilla.es/2011/10/13/fascismo-y-vanguardia-en-la-revista-de-la-ugr-afinidades/ |title='Fascismo y vanguardia', en la revista de la UGR 'Afinidades' |trans-title='Fascism and the Avant-garde', in the UGR Journal 'Afinidades' |work=El Faro de Melilla |language=Spanish |date=13 October 2011 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In 2009 she was elected president of the Spanish Association of Literary Theory (ASETEL), a position she held until 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.asetel.org/la-asociacion/ |title=La asociación |publisher=ASETEL |language=Spanish |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> During her presidency, the association's First International Congress was held.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.granadahoy.com/ocio/panorama-literario-Espana-apocaliptico_0_445156469.html |title='El panorama literario en España no es tan apocalíptico' |trans-title='The Spanish Literary Landscape is Not So Apocalyptic' |first=M. |last=De La Corte |work=Granada Hoy |location=Granada |language=Spanish |date=24 January 2011 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In March 2010 she took office as a member of the {{ill|Academia de Buenas Letras de Granada|es}}, with the reading of ''El campo y las cenizas. Imágenes del Holocausto en la poesía española de posguerra''.<ref name=Holocausto/>
==Books== * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=El irracionalismo en la poesía de Miguel Fernández |year=1983 |publisher=Antonio Ubago Editor |isbn=9788485551279 |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}<ref>{{Cite journal |url=https://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/2573122.pdf |title=Sultana Wahnon. El irracionalismo en la poesía de Miguel Fernández |first=Laura |last=Cantón |work=Aldaba: revista del Centro Asociado a la UNED de Melilla |publisher=[[National University of Distance Education|UNED]] |location=Melilla |issn=0213-7925 |number=3 |page=94 |language=Spanish |year=1984 |access-date=27 August 2018 |via=Dialnet}}</ref> * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Estética y crítica literarias en España (1940–1950) |year=1987 |publisher=EUG |location=Granada |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://revistadeliteratura.revistas.csic.es/index.php/revistadeliteratura/article/view/14/16 |title=La teoría literaria en el fin de siglo: panorama desde España |trans-title=Literary Theory at the End of the Century: Outlook from Spain |first=José-Luis |last=García Barrientos |work=Revista de Literatura |publisher=[[Spanish National Research Council]] |volume=68 |number=136 |page=408 |issn=0034-849X |doi=10.3989/revliteratura.2006.v68.i136.14 |language=Spanish |year=2006 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Saber literario y hermenéutica: en defensa de la interpretación |year=1991 |publisher=EUG |isbn=9788433813602 |location=Granada |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}} * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Introducción a la historia de las teorías literarias |year=1991 |publisher=EUG |isbn=9788433813022 |location=Granada |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}} * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Lenguaje y literatura |year=1995 |publisher=Octaedro |isbn=9788480631006 |location=Barcelona |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}<ref name=Aguirre/> * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Luis Rosales, poeta y crítico |year=1997 |publisher=Diputación Provincial de Granada |isbn=9788478071852 |editor1-first=Sultana |editor1-last=Wahnón Bensusan |editor2-first=José Carlos |editor2-last=Rosales |location=Granada |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}} * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Poesía y poética de Miguel Fernández |year=1998 |publisher=[[National University of Distance Education|UNED]] |location=Madrid |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}} * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=La estética literaria de la posguerra: del fascismo a la vanguardia |year=1998 |publisher=[[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi]] |isbn=9789042006539 |location=Amsterdam |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}} * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Kafka y la tragedia judía |year=2003 |publisher=Riopiedras |isbn=9788472131668 |location=Barcelona |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}<ref name=Rica/><ref name=vio/> * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Teoría de la literatura y de la interpretación literaria: ensayos y reflexiones |year=2008 |publisher=Academia del Hispanismo |isbn=9788496915282 |location=Vigo |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}<ref name=Maqueda/> * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=El problema de la interpretación literaria: fuentes y bases teóricas para una hermenéutica constructiva |year=2009 |publisher=Academia del Hispanismo |editor-first=Sultana |editor-last=Wahnón Bensusan |location=Vigo |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}<ref name=constructiva/> * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=En fuga irrevocable |year=2014 |publisher=Alhulia |isbn=9788415897569 |location=Granada |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}} * {{Cite book |first=Sultana |title=Perspectivas actuales de hermenéutica literaria: para otra ética de la interpretación |year=2014 |publisher=EUG |editor-first=Sultana |editor-last=Wahnón Bensusan |location=Granada| |language=Spanish |last=Wahnón}}

{{Expand Indonesian|Sundel bolong|topic=culture|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox mythical creature |name = ''Sundel bolong'' |AKA = |image = |image_size = |caption = |Mythology = [[Culture of Indonesia|Indonesian]] |Grouping = [[Legendary creature]] |Sub_Grouping = [[Vengeful ghost]], [[nocturnal]], [[undead]] |Parents = |Country = [[Indonesia]] |Region = [[Southeast Asia]] |Habitat = [[Haunted house]], [[graveyard]], area where death took place |Similar_creatures = ''[[Tai Thang Klom]]'' }} The legend of the Sundel Bolong mainly originated from the Javanese mythology. In Indonesian mythology, a '''Sundel Bolong''' is a mythical [[ghost]] from the archipelago which is a woman with beautiful long hair and a long white dress (her form is similar to [[Pontianak (folklore)|Kuntilanak]]). The myth is closely linked to [[prostitute]]s, meaning a "prostitute with a hole in her", in reference to the large hole which is said to appear in her back.
==Etymology== The name "sundel bolong" derives from the physical appearance of the ghost. The word "sundel" which means "[[prostitution|prostitute]]" or "[[whore]]" and "bolong" in [[Javanese language|Javanese]] which literally means "hole." Modern folklore studies believe that the myth was developed in Java culture to deter prostitution that developed during the [[Dutch East Indies]] colonization.
==Mythology== In folklore, Sundel Bolong is the soul of a woman who died when she was pregnant outside of marriage and therefore gave birth in her grave, or who died during childbirth and the baby came out from her back (this is the reason why the hole was created in her back)<ref name="Geertz">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-SYM4PW-YAgC&pg=PA18&dq=Sundel+Bolong#v=onepage&q=Sundel%20Bolong&f=false|title=The religion of Java|work=Anthropology/comparative religions Page 658 of Phoenix books|author=Clifford Geertz|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|year=1976|page=18|isbn=978-0-226-28510-8}}</ref> which is concealed from men by her long black hair.
Victims of Sundel Bolong spirit mainly consists of men and children. As a vengeful spirit and it is also said to be a sensitive spirit, if rejected by a man, she is said to castrate him.<ref name="Geertz" /> As for the children and mainly new born babies, she is said to take as her own for it is believed that she lost her child after birth.
''Sundel Bolong'' has appeared in a number of movies.<ref>[http://deasyelsara.wordpress.com/2012/04/05/reinterpreting-identities-in-indonesian-classic-film-poster-with-gambar-selaw/ Reinterpreting Identities in Indonesian Classic Films Poster]</ref> In 1981, an adult horror film, ''[[Sundel Bolong (1981 film)|Sundel Bolong]]'' was released, directed by [[Sisworo Gautama Putra]] and in 2007, ''[[Legenda Sundel Bolong]]'' was released.<ref>[http://film-bioskop21.blogspot.com/2012/02/film-legenda-sundel-bolong-full-movies.html Legenda Sundel Bolong]</ref>
==Popular culture== * In ''[[Marvel Anime|Marvel Anime: Blade]]'', the Sundel Bolongs are depicted as an Asian vampire sub-species. *In the horror game "''[[DreadOut]]'' " developed by Digital Happiness, Sundel Bolong is featured as one of the ghost.
==See also== {{Portal|Folklore}} *[[Bloody Mary (folklore)]] *[[White Lady (ghost)#Brazil|White Lady]] * [[Keres (mythology)|Keres]] (Κῆρες), spirits of violent or cruel death in [[Greek mythology]] *[[Onryō]] *[[Tai Thong Klom]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://postinganbiasa.blogspot.com/2012/01/review-kafan-sundel-bolong-2012.html Review: Kafan Sundel Bolong (2012)] {{Mythology of Indonesia}} [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Javanese mythology]] [[Category:Ghosts]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox Museum |name = Tate Liverpool |image = Tate Liverpool - geograph.org.uk - 903501.jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 1988 |dissolved = |location = [[Albert Dock]], [[Liverpool]], [[Merseyside]] England |type = |visitors = 628,024 (2017){{cite web|title=ALVA {{!}} Association of Leading Visitor Attractions|url=http://www.alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=423|website=www.alva.org.uk|accessdate=11 April 2018}}
* [[Most visited museums in the United Kingdom|Ranked 28th nationally]] |director = Helen Legg |curator = |publictransit = |website = [http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/ www.tate.org.uk/liverpool] |network= Tate }} '''Tate Liverpool''' is an [[art gallery]] and [[museum]] in [[Liverpool]], [[Merseyside]], England, and part of [[Tate]], along with [[Tate St Ives]], Cornwall, [[Tate Britain]], London, and [[Tate Modern]], London. The museum was an initiative of the [[Merseyside Development Corporation]]. Tate Liverpool was created to display work from the [[Tate|Tate Collection]] which comprises the national collection of British art from the year 1500 to the present day, and international modern art. The gallery also has a programme of temporary exhibitions. Until 2003, Tate Liverpool was the largest gallery of modern and [[contemporary art]] in the UK outside London. ==History== Housed in a converted warehouse within the [[Albert Dock]] on Liverpool's waterfront, the gallery was opened on 24 May 1988 by HRH Prince Charles, an event covered by BBC Two television. {{cite web|title=Tate Gallery Liverpool|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/38410f11fa6946cab62fcc8be03b61aa|website=BBC Genome, BBC Two England, 24 May 1988, 21.00|accessdate=25 May 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Youngs|first1=Ian|title=The man who's been hands-on with priceless art for 40 years|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43540079|website=BBC News|accessdate=29 March 2018|date=29 March 2018}} It is The original conversion was done by [[James Stirling (architect)|James Stirling]] but the building was given a major refurbishment in 1998 to create additional gallery space. In 2007, the foyer area was redesigned by architects Arca to create an updated appearance and better proportions, as well as to improve visitor handling. The gallery cafe was also redesigned by [[Peter Blake (artist)|Peter Blake]] and Liverpool-based architects, Architectural Emporium.{{cite web|author=Jade Wright|title=Tate Liverpool unveils Sir Peter Blake's new Dazzle cafe|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/whats-on/food-drink-news/tate-liverpool-unveils-sir-peter-9871916|website=Liverpool Echo|date= 17 August 2015|accessdate=8 January 2016}}{{cite web|title=The Tate Gallery Café|url=http://www.architectural-emporium.co.uk/project/tate/|website=Architectural Emporium|accessdate=8 January 2016}}The centrepiece of the space is a new timber desk with an undulating orange fascia, which links to the retained colour scheme of the original conversion work by Stirling. A colour-changing wall acts as a backdrop to the simplified brick volume, visible from across Albert Dock. Behind the scenes, Arca also made alterations to the hospitality, cloakroom, events and education areas. ==Live Events == The gallery has hosted numerous live events in the foyer, including Made Up Mix as part of Liverpool's Biennial of Contemporary Art.{{cite web|url=http://www.artinliverpool.com/late-at-tate-25-sept-made-up-mix/|title=Late at Tate – 25 Sept – MADE UP Mix|work=Art in Liverpool|date=24 September 2008|accessdate=22 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.biennial.com/content/LiverpoolBiennial2008MADEUP/Venues.aspx|title=Venues|work=Liverpool Biennial|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912022551/http://www.biennial.com/content/LiverpoolBiennial2008MADEUP/Venues.aspx|archivedate=12 September 2008}} This event featured Die Plankton{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/late/16339.htm|title=Made Up Mix|work=Tate Liverpool|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916072928/http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/late/16339.htm|archivedate=16 September 2008}} performing a show that was recorded for their "[https://web.archive.org/web/20111005213229/http://photos-h.ak.fbcdn.net/hphotos-ak-snc6/184002_10150274408988397_585253396_7454342_4222274_s.jpg Yorkshire's Answers To The Beatles]" live album. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons|Tate Liverpool}} * [http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/ Tate Liverpool] official site * [http://www.arca.co.uk/ Arca] * [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/smoke-and-mirrors-the-surreal-life-and-work-of-ren-magritte-2295262.html 'Smoke and mirrors: The surreal life and work of René Magritte'], ''[[The Independent]]'', 10 June 2011 {{Tate}} {{Liverpool B&S}} {{coord|53.401|-2.994|display=title}} [[Category:Tate galleries| Tate Liverpool]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Merseyside]] [[Category:Museums in Liverpool]] [[Category:Modern art museums]] [[Category:Museums sponsored by the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1988]] [[Category:1988 establishments in England]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Liverpool]] {{UK-art-display-stub}} {{UK-museum-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = The Father Christmas Letters | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:FatherChristmasLetters.JPG | caption = First edition | editor = [[Baillie Tolkien]] | author = [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] | illustrator = J. R. R. Tolkien | cover_artist = J. R. R. Tolkien | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[Fantasy]], [[children's literature]] | publisher = Allen and Unwin (1976)
Houghton Mifflin (1976)
HarperCollins (2004) | release_date = 1976, reprinted in 2004 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print (hardback & paperback) | pages = | isbn = 0-395-24981-3 |isbn_note= (1976)
{{ISBN|0-261-10386-5}} (2004) | congress = PZ7.T5744 Fat4 | oclc = 2603606 | preceded_by = [[Bilbo's Last Song]] | followed_by = [[The Silmarillion]] }} '''''The Father Christmas Letters''''', also known as '''''Letters from Father Christmas''''', are a collection of [[Letter (message)|letters]] written and illustrated by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] between 1920 and 1942 for his children, from [[Father Christmas]]. They were released posthumously by the Tolkien estate on 2 September 1976, the 3rd anniversary of Tolkien’s death. They were edited by [[Baillie Tolkien]], second wife of his youngest son, [[Christopher Tolkien|Christopher]]. The book was warmly received by critics, and it has been suggested that elements of the stories inspired parts of Tolkien's ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''. ==Plot== The stories are told in the format of a series of letters, told either from the point of view of Father Christmas or his elvish secretary. They document the adventures and misadventures of Father Christmas and his helpers, including the North Polar Bear and his two sidekick cubs, Paksu and Valkotukka. The stories include descriptions of the massive fireworks that create the [[Aurora (astronomy)|northern lights]] and how Polar Bear manages to get into trouble on more than one occasion. The 1939 letter has Father Christmas making reference to the [[Second World War]], while some of the later letters feature Father Christmas' battles against Goblins which were subsequently interpreted as being a reflection of Tolkien's views on the [[Nazi Party|German Menace]].[[#walsh|Walsh (2001)]]: p. 63 ==Publication== The letters themselves were written over a period of over 20 years to entertain Tolkien's children each Christmas. Starting in 1920 when Tolkien's oldest son was aged three,{{cite news|last=Willard|first=Nancy|title=Christmas Letters|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1976/12/05/books/tolkien-christmas.html?_r=0|accessdate=22 November 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=5 December 1976}} each Christmas Tolkien would write a letter from Father Christmas about his travels and adventures.{{cite news|title=Grand Tours: Who Travels the World in a Single Night?|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1P2-1716622/travel-etc-grand-tours-who-travels-the-world-in|accessdate=22 November 2012|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|date=22 December 2002}} Each letter was delivered in an envelope, including North Pole stamps and postage marks as designed by Tolkien.{{cite news|title=Tolkien's "Father Christmas Letters"|url=https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2001/12/07/books/tolk-christmas.slideshow_1.html|accessdate=22 November 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=7 December 2002}} Prior to publication, an exhibition of Tolkien's drawings was held at the [[Ashmolean Museum]]. These included works from ''[[The Hobbit]]'', ''Lord of the Rings'', and ''The Father Christmas Letters''.[[#johnson|Johnson (1986)]]: p. 136{{cite news|last=Lowe|first=Ian|title=Gazette: Diana Caithness|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1P2-4628707/gazette-diana-caithness|accessdate=22 November 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=13 January 1994}} {{Subscription required}} The first edition was by [[Allen and Unwin]] on 2 September 1976, three years after Tolkien's death. The [[Houghton Mifflin]] edition was released later that year on 19 October.{{cite web|title=The Father Christmas Letters|url=http://www.tolkienlibrary.com/booksbytolkien/fatherchristmas/description.htm|publisher=The Tolkien Library|accessdate=22 November 2012}} It was the third work by Tolkien to be released posthumously, after a collection of poems and the ''[[Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings]]''.[[#johnson|Johnson (1986)]]: p. 133 Edited by [[Baillie Tolkien]],[[#drew|Drew (1997)]]: p. 421 the second wife of [[Christopher Tolkien]], it includes illustrations by Tolkien for nearly all the letters; however, it omitted several letters and drawings.{{cite web|title=Letters from Father Christmas paperback (16.08.09)|url=http://www.tolkienlibrary.com/press/907-Letters_from_Father_Christmas.php|publisher=The Tolkien Library|accessdate=22 November 2012}} When the book was republished in 1999 it was retitled ''Letters from Father Christmas'' and several letters and drawings not contained in the original edition were added.[[#thompson|Thompson (2007)]]: p. 11 One edition in 1995 featured the letters and drawings contained in individual envelopes to be read in the manner they were originally conceived to be.{{cite news|title=Stocking Fillers|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1P2-4752382/stocking-fillers|accessdate=22 November 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=19 November 1995}} {{Subscription required}} ==Reception== The reception to the first two works published posthumously had been warm, which was subsequently thought to be due to Tolkien's recent death. The response to ''The Father Christmas Letters'' was much more measured and balanced. Jessica Kemball-Cook suggested in her book ''Twentieth Century Children's Writers'' that it would become known as a classic of children's literature,[[#johnson|Johnson (1986)]]: p. 188 while Nancy Willard for ''[[The New York Times]] Book Review'' also received the book positively, saying "Father Christmas lives. And never more merrily than in these pages." In 2002, an article in ''[[The Independent on Sunday]]'' described the work as rivalling "''The Lord of the Rings'' for sheer imaginative joy". ==Influence== Paul H. Kocher, whilst writing for the journal ''Mythprint'', suggested that the creatures in ''The Father Christmas Letters'' may have been a precursor to those which appeared in Tolkien's later works such as the ''[[Lord of the Rings]]'',[[#johnson|Johnson (1986)]]: p. 158 a view which was shared by Laurence and Martha Krieg in a review in the journal ''Mythlore'' (issue #14). For example, the 1933 letter features an attack on Polar Bear by a band of goblins.{{cite news|last=Garfield|first=Simon|title=Dear Santa, Please Sack Christmas Carole|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-81089339/dear-santa-please-sack-christmas-carole-radio|accessdate=22 November 2012|newspaper=The Mail on Sunday|date=23 December 2001}} {{Subscription required}} The Kriegs suggested that the wizard [[Gandalf]] may have been developed from Father Christmas.[[#johnson|Johnson (1986)]]: p. 159 ==See also== {{Portal|Children's literature}} *''[[The Life and Adventures of Santa Claus]]'', authored by [[Lyman Frank Baum]], author of the first 14 [[Oz books]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ;Sources {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Johnson|first=Judith A.|title=J. R. R. Tolkien: Six Decades of Criticism|year=1986|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn|isbn=9780313250057|ref=johnson}} *{{cite book|last=Drew|first=Bernard A.|title=The 100 Most Popular Young Adult Authors: Biographical Sketches and Bibliographies|year=1997|publisher=Libraries Unlimited|location=Englewood, CO|isbn=9780585176062|ref=drew}} *{{cite book|last=Walsh|first=Joseph J.|title=Were They Wise Men or Kings?|year=2001|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|location=Louisville, Ky.|isbn=9780664223120|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YgyzBtzU86wC&pg=PA62 |ref=walsh}} *{{cite book|last=Thompson|first=Kristen|title=The Frodo Franchise: The Lord of the Rings and Modern Hollywood|year=2007|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=9780520247741|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1odPDYvGBygC&pg=PA11 |ref=thompson}} {{refend}} {{J. Pictures]] |release_date = March 15, 1941 |color_process = [[Technicolor]] |runtime = 7:55 |movie_language = English }} '''''Tortoise Beats Hare''''' is a 1941 ''[[Merrie Melodies]]'' animated short supervised and laid out by [[Tex Avery]] (solely supervisal credited as "Fred Avery" and read by Bugs Bunny). The short, loosely based on the [[Aesop]]ian [[Aesop's fables|fable]] ''[[The Tortoise and the Hare]],'' stars [[Bugs Bunny]] and, in his first appearance, [[Cecil Turtle]]. ==Plot== As the opening credits appear, Bugs Bunny comes on the screen while eating an obligatory carrot and absent-mindedly begins reading them, grossly mispronouncing all of them in the process (e.g. {{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|v|ɛr|ɪ}} for "Avery" over the correct {{IPAc-en|ˈ|eɪ|v|ər|ɪ}}) except for the word "story," the first names of Dave Monahan and Fred Avery, and all of [[Carl W. Stalling]]'s name. As he finishes, he sees the name of the cartoon and becomes exasperated, spitting out his mouthful of the carrot he was eating. After a brief tirade involving ripping apart the opening credits, he finds Cecil Turtle and bets him ten dollars he can win against him in a race. Cecil accepts and, ringing up his cousins on a telephone, devises a scheme in which they will double as him at significant points along the track while he himself crosses the finish line ahead of Bugs and claims the money. After Bugs realizes he may have been tricked the entire time, Cecil and his cousins appear behind him, each with a dollar in hand, and kiss him. ==See also== * ''[[Tortoise Wins by a Hare]]'' * ''[[Rabbit Transit (film)|Rabbit Transit]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==Availability== DVD - ''[[Looney Tunes Golden Collection: Volume 2]]'', Disc One Blu-ray/DVD - ''[[Looney Tunes Platinum Collection: Volume 2]]'', Disc Two ==External links== * {{IMDb title|34305}} * {{bcdb title|5238}} {{s-start}} {{succession box |before = [[Elmer's Pet Rabbit]] |title = [[List of Bugs Bunny cartoons|Bugs Bunny Cartoons]] |years = 1941 |after = [[Hiawatha's Rabbit Hunt]] }} {{s-end}} {{The Tortoise and the Hare}} [[Category:1941 animated films]] [[Category:Films directed by Tex Avery]] [[Category:Running films]] [[Category:Merrie Melodies shorts]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Self-reflexive films]] [[Category:Works based on fables]] [[Category:American animated short films]] [[Category:1940s American animated films]] {{MerrieMelodies-stub}} [[Category:Films scored by Carl Stalling]]
